snippet.textDisplay: I think my friend and I only got to this point once out of months of playing. The annoying parts were the platforming like the vanishing platforms and the conveyer belts going to a pit.
snippet.textOriginal: I think my friend and I only got to this point once out of months of playing. The annoying parts were the platforming like the vanishing platforms and the conveyer belts going to a pit.

snippet.textDisplay: I was never good enough to get this far in the game, even with the turbo buttons on my NES MAX controller.  The non-stop super knee-butts only got you so far, and you could still easily fall to your death (usually out of the helicopter).
snippet.textOriginal: I was never good enough to get this far in the game, even with the turbo buttons on my NES MAX controller.  The non-stop super knee-butts only got you so far, and you could still easily fall to your death (usually out of the helicopter).

snippet.textDisplay: @RyuujinKaigetsu Spike and Hammer are their nicknames from the original DD arcade game. I'd call that original enough ;)

snippet.textOriginal: @galti111 It really does. Classic song!

snippet.textDisplay: @VGKing Not that this was the case, but if you think about it, having the controls this way really causes your mind to think with more balance. Kind of what martial arts teaches, you don't always want to punch with your right hand, you need to be able to do the same thing on both limbs equally well. Maybe the game makers were trying to sneak some of that in?
snippet.textOriginal: @VGKing Not that this was the case, but if you think about it, having the controls this way really causes your mind to think with more balance. Kind of what martial arts teaches, you don't always want to punch with your right hand, you need to be able to do the same thing on both limbs equally well. Maybe the game makers were trying to sneak some of that in?
